question.body: What is the contribution of the fourth cell (no pierced males) to the chi-squared test statistic?

response.feedback: Incorrect. It seems like you forgot to square the numerator (observed-expected). Recall that the formula for the contribution of a cell to a chi-square test statistic = (Observed - Expected)2/Expected.

Incorrect. It seems like you are dividing by the observed count instead of the expected count. Recall that the formula for the contribution of a cell to a chi-square test statistic = (Observed - Expected)2/Expected.

Incorrect. It seems like you are dividing by the table total instead of the expected count. Recall that the formula for the contribution of a cell to a chi-square test statistic = (Observed - Expected)2/Expected.

Incorrect. It seems like you are dividing by the row total instead of the expected count. Recall that the formula for the contribution of a cell to a chi-square test statistic = (Observed - Expected)2/Expected.

Incorrect. It seems like you are dividing by the column total instead of the expected count. Recall that the formula for the contribution of a cell to a chi-square test statistic = (Observed - Expected)2/Expected.
Correct. The contribution of the fourth cell (no-pierced males) to the chi-square statistic is: (Observed - Expected)2/Expected=(288-126.72)2/126.72=205.27
